Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Emergency Evacuations and Risk Communication During the 2013 Colorado Flood

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purposes of this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) are to better understand households' immediate response to a flash flood disaster in the U.S. and the short-lived aspects of disaster response data (evacuees' lasting memory). Scientists and emergency managers traditionally have used 100-year flood maps to demonstrate the occurrence of a major flood; nevertheless, flood risk is not well understood by the general public. In addition, the time required to mobilize the resources for a major post-disaster survey delays the collection of data from households but little is known about whether people's recollections of their immediate pre-impact beliefs and actions change over time. This study will use a flexible interview method and household surveys to acquire the data. The researchers will conduct field work at Colorado State (emergency manager interviews and household surveys). The interviews will help the researchers to validate the survey instruments and assess emergency managers' perspectives and experiences in the flood response. Three thousand households in the flooded areas will be identified through a random process. These households will receive the 2013 Colorado Flood response surveys during March and September 2014. Statistical analyses will be used to analyze the survey data. The researchers in this study expect to find useful emergency information that could affect the content of warning messages; risk area residents' perceptions of disaster information source and flood threat; and the speed of warning receipt and evacuation response. In addition, the result of this study can also provide empirical evidence on the recall of disaster response information.

The results of this project will benefit emergency planning professionals in the United States, as well as throughout the world by providing important tests of emergency response theories, valuable information on methods of disaster response recall information for disaster researchers, and valuable practical information for emergency managers. In particular, identification of factors that affect people's responses to floods will improve the ability of government agencies to provide the general public with more useful information about how to protect themselves and their families. The interview and survey processes will also have broader impacts on the investigators' and their research assistants' research, teaching, and learning experiences. This project will provide graduate assistants at SHSU an opportunity to participate in data collection, coding, analysis, and analytical report writing. Furthermore, the emergency manager contacts made during the field work will catalyze the investigators' future collaborations and graduate students' job prospects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study is guided by the Protective Action Decision Model. Unlike most of the PADM study, the project investigators (PIs) tested the PADM in the context of flood emergency response. This study hypothesizes that, during a flood event, people are more likely to receive warnings from peers and environmental cues, perhaps more through social media than in previous years. In addition, this study and Dr. Sudha Arlikatti’s 2013 Uttarakhand, India flood study, which also funded by the same NSF program, used a very similar questionnaire. This approach made it possible for the PIs to compare the results between United States and India. Finally, this study also tried to test people’s disaster response memory recollection by using equivalent samples.

This study sent out surveys to five counties in Colorado during April and November, 2014. For the first survey, a total of 948 questionnaires were mailed and 194 households responded, for a response rate of 20.46%. As for the second survey, the research team sent out 863 questionnaires and 208 households responded, for a response rate of 27.06%. The major findings of this study are listed below. The analyses indicated that Colorado households with higher education and income level are less likely to believe having their family members injured or killed by this flood. The study results showed that 40% of the Colorado respondents generated their initial understanding of the flood situation through personal observations, 18% relied on radio and/or television, 12% relied on their friends/relatives. Only 2% of the Colorado respondents relied on Websites for their primary flood information. On the other hand, 24% of the survey respondents reported that Website are their secondary flood information source. Many of them were highly educated and with higher income. The Colorado, U.S. and Uttarakhand, India data comparison analyses indicated that the Uttarakhand residents felt more optimistic and energetic during the floods, given the fact that they had stronger perceptions of home and community damages.  In addition, respondents in Uttarakhand reported lower levels of alertness during the flood, in contrast to Colorado respondents. Finally, this study was not able to identify any unequal correlations among variables between survey 1 (7 months) and survey 2 (14 months) using equivalent samples. This results indicated that the 7-month-after-survey and 14-month-after-survey are able to produce similar results in terms of correlations among variables. Based on this results, it is possible for researchers to wait at least 14 months to gather enough resources and send out household emergency response surveys in the future. On the other hand, since this study used equivalent samples to study this issue, the researchers were only able to identify the similarity of their correlations among variables. There is a need to conduct similar research using same household samples in the future.

This project advanced both the state of knowledge regarding household response to flood emergency in the U.S., and also the differences between the U.S. and India. In addition, the study results from testing the retention of emergency response data could help researchers to justify the timing of data collection. The interviews and survey process also had broader impact on the PIs and their research assistants’ research, teaching, and learning experiences. The PIs were able to incorporate their interview findings and survey results into course materials such as Emergency Management, Research Methods, Public Policy, and Sociology of Disaster at Sam Houston State University, Oklahoma State University, and University of Northern Colorado.
